standard_metadata.standard_description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change  and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

question.content: **What is the slope of the line?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points negative one, zero and zero, one.

hints.content: To measure slope, we pick any two points on the line. Then we look at the horizontal and vertical distances between those points.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points negative one, zero and zero, one. There is a horizontal dotted segment from zero, one to one, one that is labeled one. There is a vertical dotted segment from one, one to one, two that is labeled one.

hints.content: Going from the point on the left to the point on the right, the change in $y$ is $\purpleD 1$, and the change in $x$ is $\redD 1$.  $\begin{align} \text{Slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\redD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\redD{\Delta x}}&=\dfrac{\purpleD{1}}{\redD{1}} \\\\ &=1 \end{align}$
The slope of the line is $1$.

question.content: **What is the slope of the line?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points zero, negative three and one, negative one.

hints.content: To measure slope, we pick any two points on the line. Then we look at the horizontal and vertical distances between those points.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points zero, negative three and one, negative one. There is a horizontal dotted segment from zero, negative three to one, negative three that is labeled one. There is a vertical dotted segment from one, negative three to one, negative one that is labeled two.

hints.content: Going from the point on the left to the point on the right, the change in $y$ is $\purpleD 2$, and the change in $x$ is $\redD 1$.  $\begin{align} \text{Slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\redD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\redD{\Delta x}}&=\dfrac{\purpleD{2}}{\redD{1}} \\\\ &=2 \end{align}$
The slope of the line is $2$.

hints.content: Going from the point on the left to the point on the right, the change in $y$ is $\purpleD 3$, and the change in $x$ is $\redD 1$.  $\begin{align} \text{Slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\redD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\redD{\Delta x}}&=\dfrac{\purpleD{3}}{\redD{1}} \\\\ &=3 \end{align}$
The slope of the line is $3$.

question.content: **What is the slope of the line?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points one, two and four, four.

hints.content: To measure slope, we pick any two points on the line. Then we look at the horizontal and vertical distances between those points.    [[☃ image 1]]

There is a horizontal dotted segment from one, two to four, two that is labeled three. There is a vertical dotted segment from four, two to four, four that is labeled two.

hints.content: Going from the point on the left to the point on the right, the change in $y$ is $\purpleD 2$, and the change in $x$ is $\redD 3$.  $\text{Slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\redD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\redD{\Delta x}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{2}}{\redD{3}}$
The slope of the line is $\dfrac{2}{3}$.

question.content: **What is the slope of the line?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points zero, three and two, two.

hints.content: To measure slope, we pick any two points on the line. Then we look at the horizontal and vertical distances between those points.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points zero, three and two, two. There is a horizontal dotted segment from zero, three to two three that is labeled two. There is a vertical dotted segment from two, three to two, two that is labeled negative one.

hints.content: Going from the point on the left to the point on the right, the change in $y$ is $\purpleD{-1}$, and the change in $x$ is $\redD 2$.  $\begin{align} \text{Slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\redD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\redD{\Delta x}}&=\dfrac{\purpleD{-1}}{\redD{2}} \\\\ &=-\dfrac12 \end{align}$
The slope of the line is $-\dfrac{1}{2}$.

hints.content: To measure slope, we pick any two points on the line. Then we look at the horizontal and vertical distances between those points.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A graph of a line intersects the points one, four and four, negative four. There is a horizontal dotted segment from one, four to four, four that is labeled three. There is a vertical dotted segment from four, four to four, negative four that is labeled negative eight.

hints.content: Going from the point on the left to the point on the right, the change in $y$ is $\purpleD{-8}$, and the change in $x$ is $\redD 3$.  $\begin{align} \text{Slope}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\text{rise}}}{\redD{\text{run}}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{\Delta y}}{\redD{\Delta x}}&=\dfrac{\purpleD{-8}}{\redD{3}} \\\\ &=-\dfrac83 \end{align}$
The slope of the line is $-\dfrac{8}{3}$.
